title: Donald Trump's trip to attend Conservative Party conference is scrapped by Theresa May amid travel ban controversy
text:
News Donald Trump's trip to attend Conservative Party conference is scrapped by Theresa May amid travel ban controversy Insiders believe Trump's state visit will be in October, the same month as the Tories' gathering, and it is unlikely MPs will have the chance to vote to oppose it Share Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May has second thoughts on Trump attending Tory event (Photo: AFP) Share Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe 
Theresa May has abandoned a plan for Donald Trump to attend the Conservative Party conference. 
Insiders think the US President’s state visit will be in October, the same month as the Tories’ gathering. 
Labour MP Andrew Gwynne wrote to Conservative Party chairman Patrick McLoughlin, saying it would be “unacceptable” for Mr Trump to attend the event. 
Mr Gwynne wrote: “The President should not be welcomed to Britain while he abuses our shared values with his shameful Muslim ban and attacks on refugees’ and women’s rights.” Read More It is highly unlikely MPs will have the chance to vote to oppose Trump's state visit (Photo: Getty Images North America) 
A Tory spokesman said “there are no plans” to invite Mr Trump to the conference. 
It is highly unlikely MPs will have the chance to vote to oppose the state visit. 
They will debate the petition calling for the President to be banned, but it will be in a Parliament chamber where there is no voting. Read More Labour MP Andrew Gwynne says it would be 'unacceptable for Trump to attend the conference (Photo: Getty Images North America) 
Only the Commons Speaker John Bercow can grant a Commons vote. 
But expert David Rogers, author of By Royal Appointment, a hist­ory of the Privy Council, said it won’t happen for decisions involving the Royal Prerogative such as state visits. Like us on Facebook
